name: OWASP Top 10
description: The OWASP Top 10 is a standard awareness document for developers and web application security. It represents a broad consensus about the most critical security risks to web applications.

checklists.title: Security Code
checklists.description: Secure coding practices assessment based on OWASP ASVS, OWASP Top 10, and NIST SSDF

items.question: Is SAST (Static Application Security Testing) integrated and passing with no critical/high findings?
items.expectedEvidence: SAST scan report
items.autoTaskTitle: Integrate SAST and fix critical/high findings

items.question: Are all user inputs validated, sanitized, and parameterized (no SQL/NoSQL injection)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement input validation and parameterized queries

items.question: Is output encoding applied to prevent XSS (Cross-Site Scripting)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement output encoding for XSS prevention

items.question: Are all dependencies free of known critical CVEs (SCA scan)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Update or replace vulnerable dependencies

items.question: Is CSRF protection enabled on all state-changing endpoints?
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement CSRF protection tokens

items.question: Are error messages generic (no stack traces, internal paths, or sensitive data leaked)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Sanitize error messages in production

items.question: Are all cryptographic operations using approved algorithms (AES-256, SHA-256+, RSA 2048+)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Replace weak cryptographic algorithms

items.question: Are sensitive data fields properly classified and handled (no logging of PII/secrets)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Classify sensitive data and prevent logging of PII

items.question: Is security-focused code review performed by a trained reviewer on all PRs?
items.expectedEvidence: Code review approval records with security checklist
items.autoTaskTitle: Enforce security code review on all PRs

items.question: DAST scan coverage and pass rate
items.expectedEvidence: DAST scan report with remediation status

checklists.title: Codebase - OWASP ASVS v4.0
checklists.description: Comprehensive security verification checklist based on the OWASP Application Security Verification Standard (ASVS) v4.0. Covers architecture, authentication, session management, access control, input validation, cryptography, data protection, communications, business logic, file handling, API security, and configuration hardening.

items.question: Is the application architecture documented with clearly defined security boundaries between trusted and untrusted components, including threat modeling artifacts (e.g., STRIDE, PASTA)?
items.expectedEvidence: Architecture diagrams showing trust boundaries, threat model documents, and data flow diagrams that identify entry points and security-critical components.
items.autoTaskTitle: Document application architecture with security boundaries and threat model

items.question: Are all application components, modules, and libraries inventoried and verified to be actively maintained, with no known critical vulnerabilities?
items.autoTaskTitle: Inventory all application components and verify maintenance status

items.question: Does the application enforce strong password policies (minimum 8 characters, no maximum length below 128, no composition rules, checked against breached password lists)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement NIST 800-63b compliant password policy

items.question: Are credentials stored using a strong adaptive hashing algorithm (bcrypt, scrypt, Argon2id) with appropriate work factors, salts, and peppering?
items.expectedEvidence: Code snippets or configuration showing usage of Argon2id, bcrypt (cost >= 10), or scrypt with appropriate parameters. Evidence that plaintext or weakly hashed passwords are not stored.
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify credential storage uses Argon2id or bcrypt with proper parameters

items.question: Is multi-factor authentication (MFA) implemented and enforced for privileged accounts and sensitive operations (e.g., TOTP, WebAuthn, hardware tokens)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement multi-factor authentication for privileged accounts

items.question: Are session tokens generated using a cryptographically secure pseudo-random number generator (CSPRNG) with at least 128 bits of entropy, and are they invalidated on logout, idle timeout, and absolute timeout?
items.autoTaskTitle: Ensure session tokens use CSPRNG and enforce proper timeout policies

items.question: Are session tokens protected against fixation attacks (regenerated after authentication), and are cookie-based tokens set with Secure, HttpOnly, SameSite, and appropriate Path attributes?
items.autoTaskTitle: Harden session cookie attributes and prevent session fixation

items.question: Does the application enforce access control rules on the server side (or trusted service layer), ensuring that client-side access controls cannot be bypassed?
items.autoTaskTitle: Enforce server-side access control with deny-by-default policy

items.question: Is the principle of least privilege applied across all application layers, with role-based or attribute-based access control (RBAC/ABAC) consistently enforced and auditable?
items.expectedEvidence: Access control matrix or policy document, code showing centralized authorization enforcement, and evidence of access control unit/integration tests.
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement least-privilege RBAC/ABAC with centralized enforcement

items.question: Does the application use parameterized queries or ORM-based query builders for all database interactions to prevent SQL injection, with no raw query string concatenation?
items.autoTaskTitle: Ensure all database queries use parameterized statements or ORM

items.question: Is all user input validated on the server side using allowlists (whitelists) for type, length, range, and format, with context-appropriate output encoding applied (HTML, JavaScript, URL, CSS, SQL)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement server-side input validation and context-aware output encoding

items.question: Does the application use only current, strong cryptographic algorithms and protocols (AES-256-GCM, ChaCha20-Poly1305, RSA >= 2048, ECDSA P-256+, SHA-256+), avoiding deprecated algorithms (DES, 3DES, MD5, SHA-1, RC4)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Audit and upgrade all cryptographic algorithms to current standards

items.question: Are cryptographic keys managed securely with proper generation (CSPRNG), rotation schedules, storage in hardware security modules (HSM) or key vaults, and no hardcoded keys in source code?
items.expectedEvidence: Key management policy document, evidence of key vault integration (e.g., AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault, HashiCorp Vault), scan results showing no hardcoded keys, and key rotation schedule.
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement secure key management with vault integration and rotation policy

items.question: Is sensitive data classified and protected both at rest and in transit according to its classification level, with PII and financial data receiving the highest protection controls?
items.expectedEvidence: Data classification policy, data flow diagrams annotating sensitive fields, encryption configuration for data at rest, and evidence of TLS enforcement for data in transit.
items.autoTaskTitle: Classify sensitive data and implement protection controls per classification

items.question: Does the application prevent caching of sensitive data in HTTP responses (Cache-Control: no-store, Pragma: no-cache) and avoid storing sensitive data in browser local/session storage or logs?
items.autoTaskTitle: Prevent caching and client-side storage of sensitive data

items.question: Is TLS 1.2 or higher enforced for all connections (including internal service-to-service), with strong cipher suites, HSTS headers (max-age >= 1 year, includeSubDomains), and certificate pinning where appropriate?
items.autoTaskTitle: Enforce TLS 1.2+ with strong cipher suites and HSTS headers

items.question: Does the application enforce business logic controls to prevent abuse such as rate limiting, transaction velocity checks, and sequential step enforcement for multi-step workflows?
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement business logic abuse prevention controls

items.question: Are anti-automation controls in place to detect and prevent credential stuffing, brute-force attacks, and automated abuse of critical functionality (e.g., account lockout, CAPTCHA, progressive delays)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Deploy anti-automation controls for critical application endpoints

items.question: Are file uploads validated for type (magic bytes, not just extension), size limits enforced, files stored outside the web root with randomized names, and antivirus scanning applied?
items.autoTaskTitle: Secure file upload handling with validation and sandboxed storage

items.question: Are all API endpoints protected with proper authentication and authorization, with API keys not used as the sole authentication mechanism, and rate limiting applied per client?
items.autoTaskTitle: Secure API endpoints with authentication, authorization, and rate limiting

items.question: Does the API validate and sanitize all input parameters (query, path, body, headers), enforce strict content-type checking, and reject unexpected or oversized payloads?
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement strict API input validation and content-type enforcement

items.question: Are all security-relevant HTTP headers configured (Content-Security-Policy, X-Content-Type-Options, X-Frame-Options, Referrer-Policy, Permissions-Policy) and are server/framework version headers removed?
items.expectedEvidence: HTTP response header scan results (e.g., securityheaders.com), configuration files showing header settings, and evidence that server version banners are suppressed.
items.autoTaskTitle: Configure security HTTP headers and remove version disclosure

checklists.title: Codebase - OWASP Top 10 (2021)
checklists.description: Critical security checklist covering all ten categories of the OWASP Top 10 (2021 edition). Each category is addressed with at least two verification items to ensure comprehensive coverage of the most critical web application security risks.

items.question: Does the application enforce deny-by-default access control, ensuring that all resources and endpoints require explicit authorization grants and that users cannot access resources belonging to other users (IDOR prevention)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Enforce deny-by-default access control and prevent IDOR vulnerabilities

items.question: Are CORS policies restrictively configured, directory listing disabled, JWT tokens validated on the server, and access control checks applied uniformly at the controller/API gateway layer rather than relying on client-side enforcement?
items.expectedEvidence: CORS configuration files showing restrictive origin allowlists, evidence of server-side access control middleware, JWT validation code, and penetration test results for authorization bypass.
items.autoTaskTitle: Harden CORS, JWT validation, and centralize access control checks

items.question: Is all sensitive data (passwords, tokens, PII, financial data) encrypted at rest using AES-256 or equivalent, and are no deprecated algorithms (MD5, SHA-1, DES, RC4) used anywhere in the codebase?
items.autoTaskTitle: Encrypt sensitive data at rest and eliminate deprecated cryptographic algorithms

items.question: Is all data transmitted over TLS 1.2+ with strong cipher suites, are cryptographic keys rotated on schedule, and is forward secrecy (ECDHE) enabled for all TLS connections?
items.expectedEvidence: TLS configuration showing minimum version 1.2, cipher suite list, SSL Labs scan results (grade A or higher), key rotation policy, and certificate management procedures.
items.autoTaskTitle: Enforce TLS 1.2+ with forward secrecy and key rotation

items.question: Are parameterized queries, prepared statements, or ORM-based query builders used exclusively for all data access layers, with static analysis tools configured to detect raw query string concatenation?
items.autoTaskTitle: Eliminate injection risks with parameterized queries and SAST scanning

items.question: Is context-aware output encoding applied to prevent XSS (HTML, JavaScript, URL, CSS contexts), and are Content-Security-Policy headers deployed to mitigate the impact of any encoding bypasses?
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement context-aware output encoding and Content-Security-Policy

items.question: Has threat modeling (STRIDE, PASTA, or equivalent) been performed for the application, with identified threats tracked as security requirements and mitigations verified during code review?
items.expectedEvidence: Threat model document, list of identified threats with corresponding mitigations, evidence of security requirements in the backlog, and sign-off from security team on design review.
items.autoTaskTitle: Perform threat modeling and track security design requirements

items.question: Does the application implement defense-in-depth patterns such as rate limiting on business-critical flows, resource consumption limits, and separation of duties for sensitive operations (e.g., dual approval for financial transactions)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement defense-in-depth controls for business-critical workflows

items.question: Are all environments (dev, staging, production) hardened with unnecessary features, ports, accounts, and default credentials removed, and are security configurations managed through infrastructure-as-code with drift detection?
items.expectedEvidence: Infrastructure-as-code templates (Terraform, CloudFormation), CIS benchmark scan results, evidence of removed default accounts, and configuration drift detection alerts.
items.autoTaskTitle: Harden all environments and manage security config as code with drift detection

items.question: Are detailed error messages and stack traces suppressed in production, with generic error responses returned to users while detailed diagnostics are logged server-side only?
items.autoTaskTitle: Suppress detailed error messages in production and log diagnostics server-side

items.question: Is automated dependency scanning (e.g., Dependabot, Snyk, Renovate) enabled in the CI/CD pipeline, with a policy to remediate critical/high vulnerabilities within defined SLAs (e.g., critical within 48 hours)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Enable automated dependency scanning with vulnerability remediation SLAs

items.question: Is a Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) generated and maintained for the application, and are all direct and transitive dependencies regularly audited for known vulnerabilities and license compliance?
items.expectedEvidence: Generated SBOM document (CycloneDX or SPDX format), dependency audit report, license compliance report, and evidence of regular update cadence.
items.autoTaskTitle: Generate SBOM and audit dependencies for vulnerabilities and licenses

items.question: Are brute-force protections in place for all authentication endpoints (progressive delays, account lockout after N failed attempts, CAPTCHA), and does the application prevent credential stuffing through breached password checks?
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement brute-force protection and breached credential checks

items.question: Does the application enforce secure session management with proper token expiration, session invalidation on password change, and prevention of session fixation through token regeneration after login?
items.autoTaskTitle: Enforce secure session lifecycle management and token regeneration

items.question: Are all CI/CD pipeline artifacts (container images, packages, binaries) signed and verified before deployment, and are integrity checks (checksums, signatures) applied to downloaded dependencies and updates?
items.expectedEvidence: Artifact signing configuration (e.g., cosign, GPG), signature verification steps in CI/CD pipeline, integrity check scripts for dependencies, and evidence of subresource integrity (SRI) for CDN assets.
items.autoTaskTitle: Sign and verify all CI/CD artifacts and dependency integrity

items.question: Are deserialization operations restricted to trusted data sources with strict type constraints, and are code review processes in place to prevent insecure deserialization of untrusted data?
items.autoTaskTitle: Restrict deserialization to trusted sources with type enforcement

items.question: Does the application log all security-relevant events (authentication successes/failures, access control failures, input validation failures, privilege changes) in a structured, tamper-evident format with sufficient context for forensic analysis?
items.expectedEvidence: Sample log entries showing structured format (JSON), list of logged security events, log integrity controls (append-only, signed), and SIEM integration configuration.
items.autoTaskTitle: Implement comprehensive security event logging with tamper-evident format

items.question: Are real-time alerting and monitoring configured for suspicious activities (multiple failed logins, privilege escalation attempts, anomalous data access patterns), with incident response runbooks for each alert type?
items.autoTaskTitle: Configure real-time security alerting with incident response runbooks

items.question: Does the application validate and sanitize all user-supplied URLs and IP addresses, block requests to internal/private IP ranges (RFC 1918, link-local, loopback, cloud metadata endpoints), and enforce an allowlist for outbound connections?
items.autoTaskTitle: Prevent SSRF by validating URLs and blocking internal network access

items.question: Are network-level controls (egress firewall rules, DNS rebinding protection, cloud metadata service IMDSv2 enforcement) in place to limit the blast radius of any SSRF vulnerability that bypasses application-level controls?
items.expectedEvidence: Egress firewall rule documentation, IMDSv2 enforcement configuration, DNS rebinding protections, and network segmentation diagram showing isolation of sensitive internal services.
items.autoTaskTitle: Deploy network-level SSRF mitigations and enforce IMDSv2

checklists.title: AISystem - OWASP ML/LLM Top 10 Security
checklists.description: Comprehensive AI/ML security checklist covering the OWASP Top 10 for LLM Applications and ML-specific security risks. Addresses LLM01 (Prompt Injection), LLM02 (Insecure Output Handling), LLM03 (Training Data Poisoning), LLM04 (Model Denial of Service), LLM05 (Supply Chain Vulnerabilities), LLM06 (Sensitive Information Disclosure), LLM07 (Insecure Plugin Design), LLM08 (Excessive Agency), LLM09 (Overreliance), LLM10 (Model Theft). Additionally covers ML-specific concerns including adversarial attack resilience, data pipeline security, model versioning, and model integrity verification. This checklist ensures AI systems are hardened against the most critical security threats identified by OWASP.

items.question: Are input validation and sanitization controls implemented to detect and prevent direct and indirect prompt injection attacks, including filtering of adversarial instructions embedded in user inputs and external data sources (LLM01)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify prompt injection prevention controls

items.question: Is privilege separation enforced between the LLM and backend systems so that prompt injection cannot escalate to unauthorized actions on databases, APIs, or critical systems (LLM01)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Assess privilege separation between LLM and backend systems

items.question: Are LLM outputs validated, sanitized, and encoded before being rendered or passed to downstream systems to prevent cross-site scripting (XSS), server-side request forgery (SSRF), code injection, or other injection attacks (LLM02)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify output validation and sanitization controls for LLM responses

items.question: Are content security policies and output encoding mechanisms enforced to prevent LLM-generated outputs from executing unintended actions in client-side or server-side contexts (LLM02)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Confirm content security policies for LLM output handling

items.question: Are training data sources vetted, validated, and monitored for integrity to prevent data poisoning attacks that could introduce biases, backdoors, or incorrect behaviors into the model (LLM03)?
items.expectedEvidence: Training data provenance records, data validation pipeline documentation, integrity verification logs, and data source audit reports.
items.autoTaskTitle: Review training data integrity and poisoning prevention controls

items.question: Are data provenance tracking and supply chain verification mechanisms in place for all training, fine-tuning, and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) data sources (LLM03)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Assess data provenance tracking for AI training pipelines

items.question: Are rate limiting, input size restrictions, and resource allocation controls implemented to prevent model denial of service attacks that exhaust computational resources through crafted inputs (LLM04)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify rate limiting and resource controls against model DoS attacks

items.question: Are timeouts, token limits, and query complexity restrictions enforced to prevent resource exhaustion from excessively long or recursive prompts (LLM04)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Confirm token limits and timeout controls for AI model queries

items.question: Are supply chain security controls in place for AI/ML components, including verification of model provenance, integrity checks on pre-trained models, and security assessment of third-party ML libraries and frameworks (LLM05)?
items.expectedEvidence: Model provenance documentation, ML framework security assessment, dependency scanning results, and signed model artifact verification records.
items.autoTaskTitle: Review AI/ML supply chain security and component verification

items.question: Are controls implemented to prevent the AI system from disclosing sensitive information, including PII, proprietary data, credentials, or internal system details through its responses (LLM06)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Assess controls against sensitive information disclosure by AI

items.question: Are data sanitization and redaction mechanisms applied to training data to remove sensitive information before model training, and are output filtering mechanisms in place to catch sensitive data leakage at inference time (LLM06)?
items.expectedEvidence: Data sanitization procedures, PII redaction pipeline documentation, output filtering rules, and DLP integration evidence for AI outputs.
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify data sanitization and output filtering for sensitive data

items.question: Are plugins, tools, and extensions used by the AI system designed with security in mind, including input validation, least-privilege access, and proper authentication before executing actions (LLM07)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Evaluate security design of AI system plugins and tools

items.question: Are the AI system's permissions and capabilities limited to the minimum required for its intended function, with human-in-the-loop approval required for high-impact actions such as data modification, financial transactions, or system configuration changes (LLM08)?
items.expectedEvidence: Permission matrix for AI system actions, human-in-the-loop workflow documentation, and approval gate configurations for high-impact operations.
items.autoTaskTitle: Review AI system permission boundaries and human oversight controls

items.question: Are safeguards in place to mitigate the risks of overreliance on AI system outputs, including disclaimers, confidence scores, uncertainty indicators, and processes for human verification of critical outputs (LLM09)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify safeguards against overreliance on AI outputs

items.question: Are model assets protected against theft and unauthorized extraction, including access controls on model weights, API rate limiting to prevent model extraction attacks, and monitoring for suspicious query patterns (LLM10)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify model theft prevention controls and monitoring

items.question: Are model artifacts, weights, and configuration files encrypted at rest and in transit, with access restricted to authorized personnel and systems through role-based access controls (LLM10)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Assess model artifact encryption and access controls

items.question: Are adversarial robustness testing procedures established and regularly performed, including testing with adversarial examples, perturbation attacks, and evasion techniques specific to the model type (ML-specific)?
items.expectedEvidence: Adversarial robustness testing reports, attack simulation results, and model hardening actions taken in response to findings.
items.autoTaskTitle: Review adversarial robustness testing procedures and results

items.question: Is the ML data pipeline secured end-to-end, including data collection, preprocessing, feature engineering, and storage stages, with integrity checks and access controls at each stage (ML-specific)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Assess end-to-end ML data pipeline security controls

items.question: Is model versioning and lineage tracking implemented, including version control for model artifacts, reproducibility of training runs, and the ability to roll back to previous model versions in case of security incidents or performance degradation (ML-specific)?
items.expectedEvidence: Model version control system records, training run reproducibility evidence, model registry entries, and rollback procedure documentation.
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify model versioning, lineage tracking, and rollback capabilities

items.question: Are cryptographic integrity verification mechanisms (e.g., hash verification, digital signatures) applied to model artifacts to detect tampering during storage, transfer, and deployment (ML-specific)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify cryptographic integrity checks on model artifacts
